name: 生物地理學甲
description: Study the patterns and processes of Biogeography. Students will be introduced to both evolutionary and ecological processes that shapes the current and historical patterns of species distribution.
goals: Lectures and reading assignments will introduce students to some of the main topics in behavioral ecology
In-class discussion of research papers will improve students’ ability to think critically
syllabus:
week

1

Course introduction

2

The History of Biogeography

3

Phylogenetic inferences

4

Molecular Phylogenetics (The Voyage of Charles Darwin-V)

5

Inferring and Reconstructing Histories within and among closely-related Species— Phylogeography (The Voyage of Charles Darwin-VI)

6

The Geography of Communities;

Dispersal and Migration

7

Speciation and Extinction

8

The Changing Earth;

Glaciation and Biogeographic Dynamics of the Pleistocene

9

The Geography of Diversification

10

Reconstructing the History of Biotas

11

Island Biogeography: Patterns in Species Richness;

Island Biogeography: Assembly and Evolution of Insular Communities

12

Areography, Ecogeographic Rules, and Diversity Gradients;

Biodiversity and the Geography of Extinctions

13

Conservation Biogeography and the Biogeography of Humanity

14

The Frontiers of Biogeography

15

Special topic: Gene flow and range limits

16

Special topic: range size and richness
